nav.div: St. Clair County Regional Educational Service Agency » ABOUT RESA » Coronavirus (COVID-19) Update

div.div: RESA officials are committed to providing ongoing, accurate information to our community. This site houses all important campus notifications, resources, and latest news.

div.h3: On Friday, April 24, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer extended Michigan's Stay Safe, Stay Home order through May 15.
div.p:
The order lifts restrictions on some outdoor activities including motorized boating and golfing (without a cart). Landscaping, lawn care, plant nurseries, and bike repair shops are among those businesses allowed to reopen as along as social distancing guidelines are followed. Stores selling nonessential items can open for curbside pickup and delivery and big-box retailers can reopen their garden centers and paint/flooring/carpet areas. All other businesses remain closed. People are now required, rather than encouraged, to wear face masks when in enclosed public places such as grocery stores. The order immediately replaced one set to expire on April 30.
Executive Order 2020-59
Governor Whitmer has ordered the closure of all Michigan K-12 school buildings for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. This includes the following RESA school buildings and facilities:
div.hr:
Cancelations CPI Training for Port Huron Schools
June 17-18, 2020

a.title: COVID-19 Resources in St. Clair County

p.a: COVID-19 Community Resources in St. Clair County
p.em: The St. Clair County Community Services Coordinating Body (CSCB) has developed a website to help residents find help during the COVID-19 epidemic. The site includes links to childcare providers, financial assistance, food distribution, medical and mental health providers, unemployment and job resources, and more.

a.title: Helping Young Kids Through the Coronavirus (COVD-19) Crisis

br.a: Helping Young Kids Through the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Crisis
br.em: Information compiled by the Zero to Thrive team, led by Dr. Katherine Rosenblum

a.title: Together We Can Flatten the Curve on COVID-19 video

br.a: Together We Can Flatten the Curve on COVD-19 video
br.em: This 8-minute video by Dr. Joe Hanson from PBS's It's Okay to Be Smart explains the importance of social distancing during the COVID-19 pandemic.

div.p: You can help prevent the spread of COVID-19. Individuals can lower the risk of transmission by implementing simple, everyday practices:

ul.li: Stay home when you are sick, and advise others to do the same. Avoid close contact with people who are sick
Cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue or sleeve. Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands
Thoroughly wash hands with soap and warm water for 20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer when soap and water is not available
Ensure regular cleaning of frequently touched surfaces and objects
Eliminate handshakes and high fives, etc. with students and other staff
